64 [Mart&ydot;n]
SEint Mart&ydot;n was ibo&rrot;e &punctelev; in þe londe of sabarie Sabarie
Wel ȝong he was ino&rrot;iced &punctelev; in þe londe of papie Papie
A noble kn&ydot;ȝht is fadur was &punctelev; and Mai&slong;ter maister of þe fierde
Vnder Co&slong;tant&ydot;n þe Aumperour &punctelev; and al is . O&slong;t ost . he &slong;tierde
Fo&rrot;[al. om. r. fo&rrot;th?] into bata&ydot;le he b&rrot;ouȝhte is ȝoungue sone &punctelev; þarof him to lere
None heo&rrot;te nadde he þerto &punctelev; fo&rrot; hu&ydot; heþene were
his heo&rrot;te bar him euere to Iesu cri&slong;t Crist &punctelev; þei he icri&slong;tned nere
he isaiȝh þat heo&rrot;e bileue nas nauȝht &punctelev; þat hu&ydot; bilefden þere
¶To churche þo he was Twelf twelf ȝer old &punctelev; &slong;tilleliche he wende
And bihiet o&rrot;e louerd cri&slong;tine to beo &punctelev; ȝwane he þe time him sende
¶Þe Aumperour het[MS. hiet?] into al þat lond &punctelev; to euereche olde kniȝte
Þat heo&rrot;e sones scholden into bata&ydot;le comen &punctelev; and fo&rrot; heo&rrot;e faderes fiȝhte
So þat þe ȝungue seint Martin &punctelev; nas bote of fiftene ȝer
Þo he [þe armes][om.] in eche bataile &punctelev; fo&rrot; is fadere ber
A winter ase þis child rod &punctelev; bi þe we&ydot;e al one
A Miseise miseise man he mette naked &punctelev; so&rrot;e sike and grone
Seint Mart&ydot;n d&rrot;ovȝ out is swerd &punctelev; ase we findeth in þe bok[MS. boke]
And carf is Mantel mantel half ato &punctelev; and þe pouere Manne manne it bitok
¶Sone afturward ase he biheold &punctelev; toward heouene an heiȝh
with is halue Miseise miseise iheled &punctelev; o&rrot;e louerd cri&slong;t Crist he seiȝh
lo he seide to is Aungles aungles &punctelev; þis ne wo&rrot;th me nouȝht bireued
Martin þat is heþene ȝu&ydot;t &punctelev; herewith me hath biweued
Þo Martin þis iherde &punctelev; and o&rrot;e louerd he saiȝh þere
Glad ne bliþe nolde he beo &punctelev; are he icri&slong;tned were
¶Eiȝhtetene ȝer he was old &punctelev; þo he icri&slong;tned was
Þat he hadde so longue abide &punctelev; ofte he seide alas
Ake al þe to ȝer þareafturward &punctelev; into batailes he wende
Fo&rrot; is fader wide aboute &punctelev; ase þe Aumpero&rrot; him sende
hit bifel of a gret bataile &punctelev; þat þe Aumpero&rrot; hadde inome
he het alle is kn&ydot;ȝhtes in is lond &punctelev; þat hu&ydot; scholden to him come
he het[o&rrot;ig. hiet] Mart&ydot;n with heom wende &punctelev; and Armure armure with him take
Certes sire Martin seide þine Armes armes ich habbe fo&rrot;sake
¶Ich am Iesu cri&slong;tes Cristes kn&ydot;ȝht &punctelev; and so ich habbe ibeo longue
And none oþure Armes armes bote his &punctelev; inelle vnderfongue
Ei couward seide þe Aumperour &punctelev; nouþe þou spare&slong;t fo&rrot; fere
Fo&rrot;to fiȝhte with þine felawes &punctelev; ase þi riȝte were
Sire seide Martin þo &punctelev; þe soþe þou schalt ise
Of þine Armes armes ne kepe i nouȝht &punctelev; ake þe fur&slong;te ichulle beo
Al one bifo&rrot;e al þi folk &punctelev; naked to þe bataile
Mine louerdes miȝhte þou schalt iseo &punctelev; fo&rrot; he me nele nouȝt faile
¶Þo þat ferd alȝare was &punctelev; seint Martin wende anon
Vnarmed with is swerd ad&rrot;awe &punctelev; among alle is fon
Þo he among hem was icome &punctelev; þare nas of hem nouȝht on
Þat miȝhte ani mo&rrot;e hebbe up is hond &punctelev; þane it were a &slong;ton
hu&ydot; ȝolden him þe mai&slong;trie anon &punctelev; bote þat he let hem aliue
Seint Martin clepede is felawes &punctelev; and het hem hom wel bliue
Sire Aumperour he seide nouþe þou sixt &punctelev; ȝwuch is mi louerdes miȝhte
Are ȝe alle it hadden þarto ib&rrot;ouȝht &punctelev; longue ȝe mo&slong;ten fiȝhte
¶Nov þou ha&slong;t alle þine fon iwonne &punctelev; þonke god God and nouȝht me
And haue guod da&ydot; fo&rrot; inelle &punctelev; no lengo&rrot;e serui þe
he nam is leue and wende fo&rrot;th &punctelev; he nolde no leng abide
To þe holie bischop h&ydot;llari &punctelev; þat wonede þarebiside
Of him he was imaud acolite &punctelev; and dude al bi is rede
Ore louerd cam to him a niȝht &punctelev; and þeos wo&rrot;des to him seide
¶Ich hote þe Martin þat þou go &punctelev; wel ofte to þine kunne
And spec with hem ȝif þov miȝht &punctelev; b&rrot;ingue hem out of sunne
Þei þat hu&ydot; heþene beon &punctelev; ne let heom nouȝht þarefo&rrot;e
Fo&rrot; ech guod man schal Anouri þat kun &punctelev; þat he was of ibo&rrot;e
Ake gret anu&ydot; þov schalt habbe &punctelev; þe ȝwile þou ge&slong;t aboute
Þe ȝw&ydot;le þou mine grace ha&slong;t &punctelev; þe þarf nowiȝht doute
Þis guode Man man ase o&rrot;e louerd him het &punctelev; toward is kun wende.[o&rrot;ig. hiet]
Strongue outlawes bi þe wei he mette &punctelev; heo&rrot;e bouwes sone hu&ydot; bende
Þis guode man hu&ydot; nomen &punctelev; and maden him mani a wounde
Fo&rrot;th hu&ydot; ladden him fo&rrot;to sle &punctelev; is hondene fa&slong;te ibounde
Þe outlawes axede him ȝif he were &punctelev; so so&rrot;e ad&rrot;ad euere
Nai certes quath þis holie man &punctelev; þat[al. so siker] nas ich neuere
¶Ore louerdes help was euere neiȝh &punctelev; þe manne þat was in care
So muche is þarto min hope &punctelev; þat ine rechche hou ich fare
Of Ihesu cri&slong;t Crist he tolde so &punctelev; with heom þat him nome
Þat hu&ydot; ful sone leten him go &punctelev; and cri&slong;tine fo&rrot; him bicome
Ase þis guode Man man eode fo&rrot;th al one &punctelev; þe deuel aȝein him cam
In faire manere he axede him &punctelev; ȝwodere þene wei he nam
Þis guode Man man seide ichulle go &punctelev; ase mi louerd wole lede me
Ȝwodere þou go þe oþur seide &punctelev; þe deuel wole aȝein þe beo
¶Ȝe seide þis guode Man man &punctelev; þou mo&slong;t wel also
Fo&rrot; ȝwane o&rrot;e louerd is min help &punctelev; ine rechche ȝwat oþure do
Þis guode Man man eode among is freond &punctelev; is moder cri&slong;tine he made
his fader nolde cri&slong;tine be &punctelev; fo&rrot; al þat hu&ydot; him bede
Seint Martin fond a ȝong man ded &punctelev; þat swiþe wel with him was
Þat bilefde on o&rrot;e louerd fo&rrot; him &punctelev; ake icri&slong;tned nouȝt he nas
¶Gret deol made þis holie man &punctelev; þat he nadde ibe icri&slong;tned er
To is burieles he eode and bad fo&rrot; him &punctelev; and weop wel mani a ter
Þe dede Man man bigan anon &punctelev; fram deþe arise to liue
Martin he seide ihered beo þou &punctelev; and o&rrot;e louerdes woundes fiue
Mi soule was to helle ilad &punctelev; ase alle beoth of oure ku&ydot;nde
Ake twe&ydot;e Aungles aungles þo&rrot;uȝ godes Godes grace &punctelev; hadden me in mu&ydot;nde
And seiden o&rrot;e louerd þat ich hadde &punctelev; ouwer desciple ibeo
Þarefo&rrot;e o&rrot;e louerd me dude arise &punctelev; fo&rrot; þe honour of þe
And dude mi soule to mi bodi &punctelev; fo&rrot; þi loue hider b&rrot;ingue
Cri&slong;tinedom par charite &punctelev; ich esche bifo&rrot;e alle þingue
¶Gret Io&ydot;e ioye hadde þis holie Man man &punctelev; of þis swete cas
he nolde departi fram him nouȝht &punctelev; are he icri&slong;tned was
Þat folk nam sethþe seint Martin &punctelev; fo&rrot; he was so guod
And maden him bischop of turo&ydot;ne &punctelev; muche aȝein is mod
To mile withoute þe cite &punctelev; an Abbe&ydot;e abbeye he liet arere
Foursco&rrot;e Monekes monekes of guode liue &punctelev; himsulf he dude þere
with heom he wonede al in pa&ydot;s &punctelev; ase he heo&rrot;e soueren were
he ne wende nouȝht out bote ȝwane it neod was &punctelev; þat folk fo&rrot;to lere
¶So holi lif seint Martin ladde &punctelev; þat he hadde to is he&slong;te
Fu&ydot;r. and treo. and þe ku&ydot;nde of wo&rrot;m &punctelev; of foules and of be&slong;te
[a v. om.]A &slong;trong wind blevȝ a fu&ydot;r &punctelev; þat to seint Martines house it wende
And are þis guode man it onderȝete &punctelev; ibarnd was þat on ende
Seint Mart&ydot;n hiet a godes Godes name &punctelev; þat fu&ydot;r aȝein wiende
Fo&rrot; is he&slong;te þat fu&ydot;r flevȝ &punctelev; anon aȝein þe w&ydot;nde
To þe &slong;tude þare it cam fram &punctelev; and ne bilefde nowiȝht bihinde
And dude aȝein þe ku&ydot;nde of fu&ydot;re &punctelev; aȝein þe w&ydot;nde to fle
Þare was isene þat fu&ydot;r ne miȝhte &punctelev; aȝein is he&slong;te be
¶To is he&slong;te he hadde ase ich seide er &punctelev; þe ku&ydot;nde of þe tre
Ase ȝe mouwen bi a fair miracle &punctelev; of him nouþe iseo
On a dai ase he &slong;tod under a treo &punctelev; to p&rrot;echi godes Godes lawe
Þe luþere men þat þarebi &slong;toden &punctelev; þouȝhten him b&rrot;ingue of dawe
hu&ydot; gunne sawie þat treo ato &punctelev; toward þis holie Manne
Þat it scholde ouerfalle him &punctelev; fo&rrot; þare nadde he freond nanne
Þo&rrot;uȝ no&ydot;se of þe crakeȝingue &punctelev; þe guode man iheo&rrot;de
Þat þut treo fel touward him. &punctelev; aȝein wel sone he it cherde
¶he het þat treo a godes Godes name &punctelev; opward aȝein tu&ydot;rne
Þat treo aros upriȝht inouȝh &punctelev; fo&rrot; it nolde is he&slong;te werne
And ouerful[MS. ouerfalle] in þat oþur side &punctelev; [m]anie[MS. anie] of is fon
hu&ydot; þat leoueden lieten heom sone &punctelev; cri&slong;tni euerechon
Þe wo&rrot;m dude is he&slong;te also. &punctelev; fo&rrot; ase he cam bi a wateres b&rrot;imme
A lodlich Nadd&rrot;e naddre he isaiȝh &punctelev; &slong;tifliche aȝein him come sw&ydot;mme
Ich hote þe seide þis holie Man man &punctelev; þat þov aȝeinward wende
A[n]t þat þou neuereft here ne come &punctelev; ne nouȝwere in þis ende
Þis wo&rrot;m turnede aȝen anon &punctelev; ase þis holie Man man him het
And swam into an oþur lond &punctelev; and þulke contreiȝe furlet
¶Foules duden is he&slong;te also. &punctelev; fo&rrot; on a time ase he gan gon
he saiȝh douedoppene fisches cachche &punctelev; and swolewen heom in anon
Alas seide þis guode man &punctelev; þis is þe feondes manere
Gultlese[MS. gultlesse] þingus and vnwarre &punctelev; to cachchen ase hu&ydot; doth here
And þing þat non harm ne doth &punctelev; bote wenth in pa&ydot;[s] to beo
So farez þe deuel awa&ydot;tez euere &punctelev; fo&rrot;to he is p&rrot;eiȝe iseo
he het þe foules a godes Godes name &punctelev; echone þannes teo
And þat hu&ydot; scholden into wildernesse &punctelev; out of þat watere fleo
Þat hu&ydot; neueref[t] þare ne comen &punctelev; gultlese þingues to take
Þis foules anon with þis wo&rrot;d &punctelev; awei hu&ydot; gonne schake
¶be&slong;tes duden also is he&slong;te. &punctelev; fo&rrot; ase he wende aboute
Aftur ane hare he saiȝh vrne &punctelev; grehoundes a gret route
Alas he seide þis seli be&slong;t &punctelev; þat noþing ne doth amis
Þis foule houndes it wollez tod&rrot;awe &punctelev; gultles ase it is
he het þe grehoundes abide anon &punctelev; and ne do þat be&slong;t no wo
hu&ydot; at&slong;tunten anon and eoden aȝein &punctelev; and lieten þat be&slong;t fo&rrot;th go.[al. 2 vv. mo&rrot;e.]
¶On at&ydot;me kene houndes comen &punctelev; aboute one of is manne
he ne miȝhte him wite so kene hu&ydot; were &punctelev; ne help nadde he nanne
Ich hote eov he seide a godes Godes name &punctelev; and on seint Martines also
Þat ȝe me laten apais wende &punctelev; Min erinde fo&rrot;to do
Þe houndes anon with þat wo&rrot;d &punctelev; bigonne to &slong;tonde &slong;tille
And wenden euerech in is we&ydot; &punctelev; to do seint Martines wille
¶A kov also þat was gidi &punctelev; aboute o&rrot;n in þe londe
Þat fale men slov and be&slong;tes also &punctelev; ȝware heo fond anie &slong;tonde
hire ne miȝhte noþing at&slong;tonde aȝein &punctelev; so &slong;trong þat foule þing was
Aȝein seint Martin heo cam eo&rrot;ne &punctelev; ase o&rrot;e louerd ȝaf þat cas
So&rrot;e weren is Men men ad&rrot;adde &punctelev; þis guode Man man hire het anon
A godes Godes name &slong;tonde &slong;tille &punctelev; and [n]ane[MS. ane] fot fo&rrot;þere gon
Þat be&slong;t þei it gidi were &punctelev; anon it gan abide
Seint Martin þene deuel isaiȝ &punctelev; opon hire rugge ride
¶Þov luþere þing ȝwat do&slong;tþov þer? &punctelev; fo&rrot; euere þou do&slong;t to quede
Ȝw&ydot; trauaile&slong;t þou þat selie be&slong;t &punctelev; þat ne loueth no misdede
Aco&rrot;sede þing þou wend awei &punctelev; ne cum neiȝh hire nonmo&rrot;e
Þe deuel wende awei anon &punctelev; ȝeollinde su&ydot;þe so&rrot;e
he mo&slong;te nede is he&slong;te do &punctelev; ase wel ase þe kov
Þo heo of him deliured was &punctelev; ase ȝe ihereth hov
Mildeliche heo eode to seint Mart&ydot;n &punctelev; to is fet heo feol akneo anon
And schok hire heued to þonki him &punctelev; he nolde fram him gon
¶Seint Martin hire het arisen up &punctelev; and to ire felawes wende
heo lottede on him and eode fo&rrot;th &punctelev; hom to ire owene ende
Seint Martin was apo&slong;tlene pier &punctelev; fo&rrot; þe holie go&slong;t aliȝhte
In him ase in þe Apo&slong;tles &punctelev; in fourme of fu&ydot;r wel b&rrot;iȝhte
A dai ase þis guode Man man sat &punctelev; allone in is celle
his p&rrot;iue Men men abiden him þareoute &punctelev; and heo&rrot;den him loude telle
Also ase þei it wummen were &punctelev; hu&ydot; heo&rrot;den with him speke
Þareof hem þouȝhte wonder gret &punctelev; ne do&rrot;&slong;ten hu&ydot; nouȝt in b&rrot;eke
¶Sethþe þo þe guode man cam out &punctelev; hu&ydot; fullen adoun akneo
And axeden ȝwat þe speche were &punctelev; þat with him hadde ibeo
Þe guode man seide ich ma&ydot; eou telle &punctelev; fo&rrot; ȝe me beoz p&rrot;iue
It was o&rrot;e lauedi and seint Anneis &punctelev; þat þareinne weren with me
Of þe Io&ydot;e ioye of heouene hu&ydot; speken &punctelev; and ofte hu&ydot; doth so
Seint peter Peter and seint powel Powel &punctelev; to me comiez ofte also
Seint Martin at para&ydot;[place left vacant para&ydot; on the margin; al. paris] &punctelev; mette ane Musel musel bi cas
he cu&slong;te him and anon afturward &punctelev; þe Musel musel al hol was
¶Men ne seiȝe him neuere wroth &punctelev; ne liȝe noþemo
And ȝwatsoeuere is Men men duden &punctelev; he wolde euere bi on go
In wel pouere wede a da&ydot; &punctelev; he rod out on ane Asse asse
heiȝe Men mean he mette bi þe weie &punctelev; þat tolden of him þe lasse
heo&rrot;e ho&rrot;s weren of him ad&rrot;ad le &punctelev; fo&rrot; is pouere cloþes
And o&rrot;nen abach and felden hem adoun. &punctelev; hu&ydot; weren with him ful wroþe
hu&ydot; &slong;turten up and nomen þis holie Man man &punctelev; and beoten him ful so&rrot;e
Euere he was &slong;tille and ne spak no wo&rrot;d &punctelev; fo&rrot; þi hu&ydot; beoten him þe mo&rrot;e
¶Þo hu&ydot; him hadden so ibete &punctelev; hu&ydot; bilefden [him] atþen ende
ligginde þare and wo&rrot;þen on heo&rrot;e ho&rrot;s &punctelev; fo&rrot;th heo&rrot;e wei to wende
Ake heo&rrot;e ho&rrot;s nolden gon of þe &slong;tude &punctelev; fo&rrot; al þat hu&ydot; don[al. om.] miȝten
Ȝu&ydot;t hu&ydot;[ȝu&ydot;t hu&ydot; al. om.] smiten with ȝeo&rrot;de and with spo&rrot;e &punctelev; are þat hu&ydot; aliȝhten
And criden merci þis guode Man man &punctelev; þat hu&ydot; him hadden misdo
heo&rrot;e ho&rrot;s hem bere fo&rrot;th anon &punctelev; þo hu&ydot; token on so
And in an hous þe ȝwile it barnde &punctelev; he slep witoute harm
his cloþes furbarnden alto cole &punctelev; he ne fielde it noþing warm
¶At a gret fe&slong;te ase he scholde &punctelev; þe heiȝe masse singue
To churche he wende with is men &punctelev; men gunne aȝein him ringue
Ane pouere Man man he mette nake &punctelev; þat no schroud him nadde aboue
And bad him sumþing to helien him with &punctelev; fo&rrot; o&rrot;e louerdes loue
Seint Mart&ydot;n bad is Ercedekne &punctelev; þat he him ȝeue sum cloth
Þe Ercedekne tolde þarof lu&ydot;te &punctelev; and nolde he swo&rrot; is Oth
Seint Martin bote anne Cu&ydot;rtel cuyrtel &punctelev; on himsulf þo nadde
To þe pouere Manne manne he hine ȝaf &punctelev; in an hous þare he him ladde
¶he ne bilefde on him no cloth of wolle &punctelev; bote is Cope cope alone
Þe masse ne miȝhte he bigu&ydot;nne nouȝht &punctelev; þat folk made þarof mone
Ȝw&ydot; neltþou seide þe Ercedekne &punctelev; þine masse bigu&ydot;nne
Fo&rrot; þou mo&slong;t er ane pouere Manne manne &punctelev; sum cloth to him iwinne
Nov is þis[erased? al. hit] seide þe Ercedekne &punctelev; gret anu&ydot; with þe
Fo&rrot; jne seo no pouere Man man &punctelev; nouȝwere aboute þe be
No seide þis holie man &punctelev; it nele faillie þe nouȝht
Al redi þou finde&slong;t a pouere Man man &punctelev; habbe þou þat cloth ibrouȝth
¶Þe Ercedekne in grete wrathþe &punctelev; eode into chepingue
A lodlich cloth he bouȝhte fo&rrot; fif panes &punctelev; to þe bischope he gan it b&rrot;ingue
Þe bischop eode into þe ve&slong;tiarie &punctelev; is Cope cope he gan of &slong;trepe
he nadde under is ve&slong;timenz &punctelev; to habbe on bote þis[o&rrot;ig. is] Iu&ydot;pe
Vnneþe it heolede is derne limes &punctelev; and nouȝht folliche is elbouwes
